title: Horner Syndrome
scope: ** Evaluation and localization of Horner syndrome in adults and children. Includes pharmacologic confirmation, three-neuron localization (first-order central, second-order preganglionic, third-order postganglionic), and etiology-specific workup. Covers ED evaluation of acute Horner syndrome (emergent — dissection until proven otherwise), inpatient evaluation, and outpatient evaluation of chronic or incidental Horner. This is fundamentally a localization and diagnostic template — treatment depends on the underlying etiology.

Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.timing: Emergent — within 1 hour for acute painful Horner; fastest modality for dissection detection
Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.target: No carotid/vertebral dissection; no aneurysm; no mass compressing sympathetic chain
Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment (hydrate; weigh risk/benefit — dissection is life-threatening)

Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.item: MRI brain with/without contrast + MRA head and neck (CPT 70553, 70547, 70549)
Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.timing: If CTA not immediately available or as follow-up; includes fat-sat sequences for dissection
Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.target: No brainstem/hypothalamic lesion (first-order); no dissection (third-order); no mass

Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.timing: All Horner syndrome patients; screen for Pancoast tumor (apical lung mass); mediastinal mass
Essential Studies (ALL Acute Horner Synd.target: Clear lung apices; no apical mass; no mediastinal widening

Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).timing: Confirms diagnosis of Horner syndrome; can be done at bedside
Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).target: Apraclonidine: Horner pupil dilates (reversal sign due to denervation supersensitivity), normal pupil constricts or unchanged; Cocaine: Horner pupil fails to dilate, normal pupil dilates
Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).contraindications: Active anterior chamber inflammation; closed-angle glaucoma risk; avoid in infants <6 months (apraclonidine can cause CNS depression)

Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).timing: Localize lesion: 1st/2nd order (pupil dilates) vs 3rd order (pupil fails to dilate); must wait 48h after cocaine/apraclonidine
Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).target: Dilation = intact postganglionic neuron (1st or 2nd order); no dilation = postganglionic lesion (3rd order)

Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).timing: If Pancoast tumor suspected on CXR or clinical suspicion (2nd-order lesion with arm pain, T1 distribution weakness/numbness)
Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).target: No apical mass; characterize mass if present

Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).timing: First-order or second-order Horner; evaluate for syringomyelia, demyelination, spinal cord tumor, disc herniation
Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).target: No cord lesion; no syrinx; no mass

Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).item: MRI brain with contrast (specifically including cavernous sinus protocol)
Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).timing: Third-order (postganglionic) Horner; cavernous sinus pathology; parasellar mass
Extended Studies (Localization-Specific).target: No cavernous sinus mass; no skull base tumor; no cavernous ICA aneurysm

Emergent Treatment (Carotid/Vertebral Di.indication: Carotid or vertebral dissection confirmed on imaging; prevent thromboembolic stroke from dissection

doseOptions.orderSentence: Anticoagulation (heparin → warfarin or DOAC) Heparin IV

dosing.instructions: Heparin 80 units/kg bolus then 18 units/kg/hr; target aPTT 60-80 sec; transition to warfarin (INR 2-3) or DOAC (apixaban 5 mg BID or rivaroxaban 20 mg daily) for 3-6 months

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (emergent) for acute painful Horner syndrome — evaluate for dissection, stroke, and initiate acute management
Neuro-ophthalmology for pharmacologic confirmation (apraclonidine/hydroxyamphetamine testing), pupil assessment, and chronic Horner evaluation
Vascular surgery/interventional neurology if carotid dissection with pseudoaneurysm or flow-limiting stenosis requiring intervention
Thoracic surgery/oncology if Pancoast tumor identified; staging and treatment planning
Ophthalmology for children with congenital Horner — evaluate for iris heterochromia and amblyopia; monitor for neuroblastoma
Pediatrics/pediatric oncology if Horner in child <2 years — neuroblastoma must be excluded (chest/abdomen imaging, urine catecholamines)

Patient Instructions.item: Seek immediate emergency care if you develop sudden severe headache, neck pain, face pain, weakness or numbness on one side, trouble speaking, or vision loss — these could indicate stroke from carotid dissection
The droopy eyelid and small pupil are caused by nerve damage to the sympathetic chain — in most cases the cosmetic effect is mild and does not affect vision
If the underlying cause is treated (e.g., dissection resolves), the Horner syndrome may partially or fully resolve over weeks to months, though permanent mild ptosis/miosis may persist
Attend all follow-up imaging appointments — dissections require repeat imaging at 3-6 months to confirm healing; tumors require staging and monitoring
Do not take blood thinners or aspirin without medical guidance — if you are on anticoagulation for dissection, follow dosing instructions precisely and report any bleeding immediately

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: If cervical artery dissection: avoid neck manipulation (chiropractic), extreme neck extension/rotation, and contact sports until dissection is confirmed healed on repeat imaging (typically 3-6 months)
Optimize cardiovascular risk factors if dissection-related (BP control, cholesterol management, smoking cessation)
Protect the eye on the affected side: ptosis may reduce natural eye protection; use lubricating drops if dryness develops; annual ophthalmologic exam

differential.features: Difference in pupil size is <1 mm and constant in light and dark; no ptosis; no anhidrosis; present since birth in ~20% of population
differential.tests: Pupil difference constant in all lighting conditions; no dilation lag; pharmacologic testing negative

differential.features: Ptosis (more severe, often >2 mm); pupil DILATED (not constricted); extraocular movement deficit (especially adduction, elevation, depression)
differential.tests: Complete neuro-ophthalmologic exam; pupil is large (not small); MRI/MRA for aneurysm

differential.features: Large (dilated) tonic pupil, not miotic; sluggish light reaction with vermiform movements; may have absent DTRs
differential.tests: Dilute pilocarpine 0.1% (supersensitive constriction); slit lamp showing vermiform movements; pupil is larger, not smaller

differential.features: Ptosis without miosis or anhidrosis; may be bilateral; fluctuating in myasthenia; dermatochalasis is redundant skin
differential.tests: Normal pupils; ice pack test or acetylcholine receptor antibodies for MG; dermatochalasis — skin exam

differential.features: Horner syndrome occurs during cluster attacks (ipsilateral ptosis, miosis); autonomic features (tearing, rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection); resolves between attacks
differential.tests: Clinical history; Horner resolves between cluster periods; MRI normal

differential.features: Most important cause to exclude; acute Horner + ipsilateral head/neck/face pain; may have partial Horner
differential.tests: CTA/MRA neck showing dissection; fat-suppressed MRI showing intramural hematoma

differential.features: Second-order Horner; arm pain (C8-T1 distribution); hand weakness/wasting; may have shoulder pain
differential.tests: Chest X-ray (apical mass); CT chest with contrast; tissue biopsy

differential.features: First-order Horner; ipsilateral facial pain/numbness; contralateral body pain/temperature loss; ataxia; dysphagia; vertigo
differential.tests: MRI brain (DWI showing lateral medullary infarct); MRA showing PICA or vertebral occlusion

differential.features: Present since birth; iris heterochromia (affected iris lighter); no new symptoms
differential.tests: Birth history; iris color difference; old photographs; workup to exclude neuroblastoma in children

evidence.recommendation: Acute painful Horner syndrome requires emergent vascular imaging to exclude carotid/vertebral dissection
Apraclonidine 0.5-1% has replaced cocaine as the preferred pharmacologic test for confirming Horner syndrome
CADISS trial: antiplatelet vs anticoagulation for cervical artery dissection showed no significant difference in stroke prevention
Pediatric Horner syndrome requires neuroblastoma screening (urine catecholamines, chest/abdomen imaging) in children <2 years
Hydroxyamphetamine test localizes postganglionic (3rd-order) lesions with high specificity
evidence.source: [Maloney WF et al. Am J Ophthalmol 1980](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7425056/)

evidence.recommendation: Wallenberg syndrome is the most common central (1st-order) cause of Horner syndrome
Three-neuron anatomic pathway of oculosympathetic system and clinical localization

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (pupil, ptosis, facial sweating, motor/sensory exam)
monitoring.frequency: Each encounter; q4h if acute dissection
monitoring.action: Emergent re-imaging if new deficits; adjust anticoagulation; neurosurgical consultation

monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months after initial diagnosis; then as clinically indicated
monitoring.action: Continue anticoagulation if persistent; vascular surgery referral for expanding pseudoaneurysm
Amblyopia treatment if detected; continued neuroblastoma surveillance in young children

monitoring.item: Tumor surveillance (if etiology is Pancoast or other malignancy)

monitoring.action: Ptosis repair surgery (Muller muscle-conjunctival resection) for cosmetic or functional concern if stable and desired

disposition.criteria: Acute Horner with NEGATIVE vascular imaging (no dissection); no stroke; benign etiology suspected; neurology/neuro-ophthalmology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; outpatient MRI if not yet obtained
Awaiting MRI/MRA results; borderline imaging findings requiring vascular surgery input; new Horner without pain — may warrant brief observation while imaging completed
Confirmed carotid/vertebral dissection (anticoagulation initiation, serial neuro exams); stroke associated with dissection; Pancoast tumor workup; new neurologic deficits with Horner
Acute dissection with large stroke; dissection with progressive neurologic deficit; hemorrhagic conversion of dissection-related stroke; hemodynamic instability

Chronic/incidental Horner: within 2-4 weeks for pharmacologic testing and localization; post-dissection: 2 weeks (clinical), 3-6 months (repeat imaging); pediatric: urgent if <2 years (neuroblastoma exclusion)
